"WIN THE WAR DAY" IN THE
COLLEGES
By WILLIAM MATHER LEWIS

(From the Patriotic News Service
of the National Committee of Patriotic Societies, Washington, D. C.)

A plan to observe April 6, the
first anniversary of America's entry into the war as "National Win
the War Day" has been worked
out by the National Committee of
Patriotic Societies.
A statement sent out to the
presidents of fifty National Patriotic Organizations, to, Cabinet
members and other Government
officials and to college presidents,
says:"At the beginning of our sec,
ond year in the great war it is fitting that we have a National consecration to the task remaining
before up. Because of numerous
workless days during the past winter it is not advisable that the occasion should be made a holiday,
but in every factory, store, mine,
school and on every farm there
should be a brief period during
the day where everyone who is
loyal to the flag should stand up
and be counted. Flags should
every where be unfurled. At 12
o'clock noon factory whistles and
church bells should send forth a
volume of sound that will reach
Berlin. Every band in the country will then play 'The StarSpangled Banner,' while people
stand at attention. In the evening
in the churches, halls and. theatres
the people-can gather for meetings
of inspiration. Regiments of the
National Army may parade in
cities 'near the cantonments.
"The 'winter of our discontent'
with its coalless days and congest
ed railroad and other minor annoyances is past. The spring with
its promise of abundant crops and
increased industrial production is
here. Now is the time for America's Home Army to mobilize and
thus bring courage to our boys in
the trenches and cantonments, and
depression to our enemies. Let
Germany feel that this is a popular
war in America. The effect of having the nation a unit in patriotic
thought on this • day cannot be
over-estimated.
"In every college there shouldbe special patriotic exercises at
which messages from students
and alumni in the nation's service
may be read, instruction as to how
every college student can do his
part to win. the war can be given
and a pledge of allegiance to the
flag and the cause of the war repeated by all. The colleges of
America have responded nobly to
the call to Arms: On April 6 faculties and • students should let
their brothers in the field know
that they. are ,with them in spirit
and in effort."

under Trotsky and Lenine, the

are optimistic and are looking for
a true leader to save them and
their country.

all like the popular conceptions
formed about them. Major Billings said he saw no signs of disorder anywhere exceeding the ordinary disorders in this country.

peaceable, and, although oppressed
and stunted intellectually, they
kept cheerful countenances, and
make the most of their hardships

of Russia if we do not want Russia

The Adams Contest.

The Adams Debate and PublicSpeaking Contest, which will take
place on next Saturday evening,
is an event in which .every Hopkins undergraduate should be sufficiently interested to attend. A
,debate and an oratorical contest
.cannot be said to be a drawing attraction,even in a'clemocracy where
the theoretical basis .of the Government is public discussion and
in a university _ where mental
training
traininfris the fundainental purpose.
the Adams contest is
mote than 'a debate and an oratorical contest it-Is-the one annual occasion in which the rivalry
of the upper •classmen is revived
and aired; it is one of the rare occasions when the oldest of the
lower classes indulge.,in an intellectual celebration as well as when
the musical _organizationS present
their fellows with an exhibition
of real harmony. In other words,
the Adams Contest is the one official indoor sport- staged particularly for the Hopkins undergraduate body.
The Adams contest is likewise
unique in the 'Sense that it is the
only official occasion upon Which
Hopkins students give a practical
and public demonstration ,of the
value of their college work. The
criticism is often introduced that
college men think well, but usually of themselves, and rarely are
they able to intelligently express
the products of their thought. A
public debate on a living public
question is a satisfactory answer
to this criticism. But the debate
in itself is an answer for only a

handful of men; a large and interested, audience of Hopkins men is
irrefutable proof of the practical
value of a college education.
If the intellectual argument for

At a meeting of the Athletic

graduate-manager who can keep
in very close contact with the
team managers and the student
body. Leber is an excellent man
for the job, as he has had considerable experience as assistant
manager of the track team, and in
arranging the details of the parades and rooting during the past
football season.

elected manager of the football
team for next fall. Evans has been
assistant manager of the team for
two years, serving as first assistant last fall. The spring schedules

made to arrange a lacrosse game

(From the Patriotic News Service

A plan to observe April 6, the
first anniversary of America's entry into the war as "National Win
the War Day" has been worked
out by the National Committee of
Patriotic Societies.
A statement sent out to the
presidents of fifty National Patriotic Organizations, to, Cabinet
members and other Government
officials and to college presidents,
says:"At the beginning of our sec,
ond year in the great war it is fitting that we have a National consecration to the task remaining
before up. Because of numerous
workless days during the past winter it is not advisable that the occasion should be made a holiday,
but in every factory, store, mine,
school and on every farm there
should be a brief period during
the day where everyone who is
loyal to the flag should stand up
and be counted. Flags should
every where be unfurled. At 12
o'clock noon factory whistles and
church bells should send forth a
volume of sound that will reach
Berlin. Every band in the country will then play 'The StarSpangled Banner,' while people
stand at attention. In the evening
in the churches, halls and. theatres
the people-can gather for meetings
of inspiration. Regiments of the
National Army may parade in
cities 'near the cantonments.
"The 'winter of our discontent'
with its coalless days and congest
ed railroad and other minor annoyances is past. The spring with
its promise of abundant crops and
increased industrial production is
here. Now is the time for America's Home Army to mobilize and
thus bring courage to our boys in
the trenches and cantonments, and
depression to our enemies. Let
Germany feel that this is a popular
war in America. The effect of having the nation a unit in patriotic
thought on this • day cannot be
over-estimated.
"In every college there shouldbe special patriotic exercises at
which messages from students
and alumni in the nation's service
may be read, instruction as to how
every college student can do his
part to win. the war can be given
and a pledge of allegiance to the
flag and the cause of the war repeated by all. The colleges of
America have responded nobly to
the call to Arms: On April 6 faculties and • students should let
their brothers in the field know
that they. are ,with them in spirit
and in effort."

On last Sunday evening Dr.
George E. Barnett spoke to a meeting of the Amalgamated Clothing
Makers on Unemployment.
"Unemployment," Dr. Barnett
said, "is that condition in which
a man finds himself when he is
willing to work, but is unable to
find work." The evils of unemploymen are fourfold: Unemployment
is the cause of poverty; it is the
chief cause of industrial friction;
it represents a loss of productive
power, and it stands in the way
of the solution of other social
problems.
The extent of unemployment
can be learned from a study of the
data gathered by the English
trade Unions. According to these
statistics, at least 2 per cent. of
the workers have been out of work
all the time for the last 30 years;
the greatest number out of work
for the same period at different
times has been 11 per cent.
To attack the evil, two methods
are possible: Discover the cause
and eradicate it, or devise a method whereby the evil may be mitigated. There are two kinds of unemployment: First, there is seasonal unemployment, which is the
mose general. At one time the anthracite coal workers were without jobs from the spring to the
fall. As no one purchased coaluntil the fall, no one was needed
to mine the coal until the fall. An
investigation, however, brought to
light the fact, that coal was sold
for the same price all year round.
To induce people to buy in the
summer, a reduction in price was
offered to people who purchased in
that season. The anthracite coal
workers were soon employed
throughout the year. Another way
to reduce the evil is to make arrangements whereby it will be possible for people to work in different industries at different times
of the year. The second kind of
unemployment is that which comes
with an industrial depression.
The evil resulting from this kind
of unemployment could be abated
if the Government should postpone
some of its undertakings for such
a period.
All this; unfortunately, will not
do away with unemployment. The
best course for the worker to follow is to insure himself akairist

was instituted in England in 1912.

team managers and the student

arranging the details of the parades and rooting during the past
